intro: Elleanthus vitellinus, commonly known as the yellow-eyed grass, is a flowering plant native to eastern North America. It belongs to the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and narrow leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in dense clusters, giving it its common name. It typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of ponds, preferring moist to wet soil conditions. Elleanthus vitellinus is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and provide habitat for various wildlife species.
